Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Permian and Triassic Icehouse to Greenhouse Paleoenvironments and Paleobotany in the Shackleton Glacier Area, Antarctica
Award.AbstractNarration:
The focus of this collaborative project is to collect fossil plants, wood, and sedimentary and chemical information from rocks in the Shackleton Glacier (SHK) area of Antarctica. This information will be used to reconstruct plant life and environments during the Permian and Triassic (~295-205 million years ago) in Antarctica. This time interval is important to study as Antarctica experienced a large glaciation in the Permian followed by deglaciation and recovery of plant and animal life, only to be subjected to the largest extinction in Earth history at the end of the Permian. After the extinction events, the climate in Antarctica continued to warm extensively and there were forests growing close to the paleo-South Pole. These ancient environments provide a natural laboratory in which to study the effects of climate change on plant life. The results of this project will advance the field in the areas of changing sedimentary patterns during global cooling and warming, as well as plant evolution during times following glaciation and during global warmth.

This project will study the extent of the Gondwana glaciation in the SHK area, the invasion and subsequent flourishing of life following glacial retreat, and the eventual recovery of plant life after Late Permian extinction events. Only in Antarctica does a complete polar-to-near-polar succession occur across this climatic and biologic transition. The SHK area is an important one as it is one of the few regions in the world where the Permian-Triassic boundary (PTB) is exposed within terrestrial rocks. The field and lab work for this project is organized around three hypotheses that address fundamental issues in Earth history, including changes in the extent and diversity of flora during the Permian build up to the Late Paleozoic Ice Age, the possible diachronous nature of the PTB, and that poor fossil preservation during the Early Triassic has given a false impression that Antarctica was devoid of plants during this time. The hypotheses will be tested by integrating various types of paleobotanical approaches with detailed sedimentology, stratigraphy, and geochemistry. Compression floras and petrified wood will be collected (constrained by stratigraphy) both quantitatively and qualitatively in order to obtain biodiversity and abundance data, and as a data source for paleoecological analysis. Standard sedimentologic and stratigraphic analyses will be performed, as well as paleosol analyses, including mineralogic and major- and trace-element geochemistry. Collections will also be made for U-Pb zircon geochronology to better constrain geologic and biotic events through time. Results of the project will be incorporated into educational and outreach activities that are designed to include women and under-represented groups in the excitement of Antarctic earth sciences and paleontology, including workshops in Kansas and Wisconsin, as well as links to science classes during fieldwork.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research was designed as a collaborative project to gather new information on the Permian and Triassic floras and paleoenvironments in the Shackleton Glacier area, central Transantarctic Mountains, Antarctica. The largest mass extinction of all time occurred at the end of the Permian period (around 250 million years ago). Unlike today, Antarctica was forested at that time, even though it was positioned at very high latitudes. Our field teams collected fossil plants and fossil wood, while our collaborators gathered data related to the rocks containing the fossils. From the Early Permian through to the Middle Triassic, Antarctica changed from glaciated to forested and from an icehouse to a greenhouse climate, including the eventual recovery of plant life after the Late Permian extinctions.

In the first season of fieldwork (2015-2016 austral summer), a new petrified forest site was discovered. Trees were in growth position with tree rings preserved, and the site is Lower Permian in age. Nearby, compression fossils of Glossopteris and Gangamopteris (extinct seed plants) and at least 2 species of Paracalamites (a non-seed plant) were uncovered. All of these leaves are intermixed and can all occur on the same rock slab. There are very few Lower Permian floras known from Antarctica. The fossil forest is important in that it provides a view of an ecosystem prior to the end-Permian mass extinction. In addition, Lower Permian floras in general are important to examine, as they (should) show low diversity, as it has been assumed that Antarctica was still recovering from the Late Carboniferous glaciations during this time, so the cooler climate resulted in floras with lower diversity.

The second season of fieldwork (2016-2017 austral summer) was very successful. Collections included increased evidence of Middle Triassic plant diversity at these higher polar latitudes, specifically gymnosperm (seed fern) reproductive structures, additional types of ferns and unusual growth structures and branching patterns in some plants. Several new deposits of silicified chert were discovered and some of these contain anatomically preserved (petrified) plants. Chert is an important discovery as it preserves petrified plants with their cellular structure intact. Perhaps the most significant discovery was several different layers of chert on Collinson Ridge, a site which contains the Permian-Triassic boundary. Very large, in situ stumps were also found there, indicating lush plant growth at high paleolatitudes at this time. The chert (Late Permian in age) contains a greater diversity than that found so far at other sites with petrified plants in the central Transantarctic Mountains, including several different types of stems, leaf mats and at least three (maybe four) different types of seeds. Overall, the collections made during these two field seasons will contribute a great deal of information from plants about the environment in Antarctica during these time periods, including the changes in plant diversity between the Permian and the Triassic periods.
